# Draft:Politburo of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party

}}}}|image=Emblem of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (1930s to 1990).svg|imagesize=|imagecaption=|leader=Jambyn Batmonkh|leader_title=General Secretary|elected_by=Central Committee|responsible_to=Central Committee|seats=9|meeting_place=Government Palace, Ulaanbaatar|picture=}}The Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the '''Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party'''}} was the highest decision-making body of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, the sole legal party that ruled the Mongolian People's Republic from the People's Revolution of 1921 until the Democratic Revolution of 1990.
Currently, the bureau is a group of 17 top officials who oversee the party and central government. The politburo is headed by the general secretary. Unlike the politburos of other communist parties, the WPK Politburo subdelegates many of its powers to the smaller Politburo Presidium.
The Politburo is elected by the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea, and is the highest decision-making body in WPK between sessions of the Central Committee. Article 25 of the Party Charter stipulates that "The Political Bureau of the Party Central Committee and its Presidium organize and direct all party work on behalf of the party Central Committee between plenary meetings. The Political Bureau of the Party Central Committee shall meet at least once every month."
The following is the composition of the Politburo that would be formed after every Congress of the Party. The politburo for the 1941–48 period is not included.

Generally, the Central Committee approved Politburo reports and policy decisions. The Secretariat was responsible for guiding the day-to-day affairs of the Party, in particular for organising the execution of Politburo decisions and for selecting Party and government cadres.
